subject: physics
title: Transversal and Longitudinal Waves MCQ Problems

problems.question: In a transverse wave, how do the particles of the medium move relative to the direction of wave propagation?
problems.detailed: In a transverse wave, particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation, forming crests and troughs.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which of these is an example of a longitudinal wave?
problems.hint: Longitudinal waves use compressions and rarefactions.
problems.detailed: Sound waves in air are longitudinal: particles oscillate parallel to wave direction, creating compressions and rarefactions.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which property can **only** transverse waves have (not longitudinal)?
problems.detailed: Transverse waves have clearly defined crests and troughs. Longitudinal waves have compressions and rarefactions instead.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which type of wave **cannot be polarized**?
problems.hint: Polarization is restricting the direction of vibration; see which wave type doesn’t allow that.
problems.detailed: Longitudinal waves can’t be polarized because their vibrations occur in the same direction as propagation (no perpendicular component to restrict).
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which of these is **not** a valid example of a transverse wave?
problems.detailed: Light, string waves, and water waves are transverse. Sound in air is longitudinal, so it is not transverse.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov
